full_title_en: EGSYS (Evaluation of Guidelines in SYncope Study) Score for Syncope
medium_description_en: Predicts likelihood that syncope is from cardiac cause.
instructions_en: Note: We recommend the San Francisco Syncope Rule over other syncope risk stratification scores, as it is the most widely validated.
search_abbreviation_en: Evaluation of of Guidelines in Syncope Study

seo.meta_description_en: The EGSYS Score for Syncope identifies cardiac causes of syncope.
seo.keywords_en: EGSYS, Evaluation of Guidelines in SYncope Study, syncope, syncope score, fainting, vasovagal, LOC, ROSE, OESIL canadian syncope score

how_to_use.use_case_en: Patients presenting to the emergency department with syncope.
how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• May have limited generalizability—in the study, a cardiologist specializing in syncope was available to review the EKG in the emergency setting.
  • Includes specific criteria for EKG abnormalities.
  • Less sensitive (95%) than the San Francisco Syncope Rule (96–98%).
how_to_use.why_use_en: Cardiac syncope carries high mortality if untreated. A score that identifies these patients can help prevent adverse outcomes from underlying cardiac pathology.

next_steps.advice_en: The EGSYS authors suggest the score be used as an aid for emergency physicians for screening, not as a substitute for clinical judgment in syncope management.
next_steps.critical_actions_en: Patients with suspected cardiogenic syncope should be referred to a cardiologist.

  1. Sinus bradycardia, AV block >1st degree, BBB, acute or old MI, SVT or VT, left or right ventricular hypertrophy, ventricular preexcitation, long QT, or Brugada pattern.
  2. Previous clinical or laboratory diagnosis of any form of structural heart disease, including ischemic heart disease, valvular dysfunction, myocardiopathies and congenital heart disease; previous diagnosis or clinical evidence of CHF; physical signs of structural heart disease.
  3. Nausea/vomiting.
  4. Warm or crowded place, prolonged orthostasis, fear/pain/other emotion.
